nodes.title: Drakkar Yungdrung Khyütsé Sangchen Mindröl Ling Introduction

nodes.body: The full name of the hermitage, which is actually a nunnery, is Brag dkar g-yung drung ’khyud rtse gsang chen smin grol gling.
nodes.title: 1. Name

nodes.body: The hermitage is located 2 km on foot from dGa’ mal Monastery (No.208), at the top of the mountain behind the monastery, 34 km from Songpan, the seat of Zung chu county.
nodes.title: 2. Location

nodes.body:
Brag g-yung drung is a hermitage of dGa’ mal Monastery. Its history is practically unknown. There are hermits who live in separate quarters.

In the 1980s Tshul khrims rnam dag, the forest guardian, who has lived as a tantric practitioner at the site for many years, obtained permission to build a nunnery. This is the only Bonpo nunnery in the area.
nodes.title: 3. History

nodes.body: There are twenty-six nuns in the nunnery and fifteen monk hermits.
nodes.title: 5. Number of hermits

nodes.body: The nuns are trained by the master of the nunnery either collectively or individually.
nodes.title: 6. Current education

nodes.body: The nunnery maintains close ties with dGa’ mal Monastery, which sends teachers there.
nodes.title: 7. Educational exchange

nodes.body:
The main ritual practice of the nunnery is based on the cycle of Ma rgyud, but there is also performance of rituals as follows:

  • 2nd month: practice of meditation in conjunction with a ceremony based on the rDzogs chen sku gsum rang shar by Shar rdza bKra shis rgyal mtshan
  • 4th month: the ritual practice based on the Tshe dbang bod yul ma by gYung drung gling pa, from the 4th to the 15th day
  • 6th month: the ritual practice based on the mKha’ ’gro gsang gcod by sPrul sku Khro gnyan rgyal mtsahn on the 14th and 15th days
  • 8th month: the ritual cycle of Ma rgyud on the 24th and 25th days finishing with a ’cham dance
nodes.title: 8 / 9. Rituals

nodes.body: The nunnery has no regular Sources of income and depends on offerings from the faithful; the nuns and hermits provide their own food.
